sols:
From the initial form of the derivative, as computed in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (a)}{part
(a)},

\[f'(x) = \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5}\]

we find that the second derivative is

\[\begin{align}
f''(x) &= \left(\frac65\right)\left(-\frac45\right)x^{-9/5} + \left(\frac65\right)\left(\frac15\right)x^{-4/5} \\
&= \frac6{25}\left(-4x^{-9/5}+x^{-4/5}\right) \\
&= \frac6{25x^{9/5}}(-4+x)
\end{align}\]
Using the compact form of the derivative, as computed in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (b)}{part
(b)},

\[\begin{align}
f'(x) &= \frac{6(x+1)}{5x^{4/5}}
\end{align}\]

we find the second derivative by taking the quotient rule:

\[\begin{align}
f''(x) &= \frac{6}{5} \left( \frac{x^{4/5}-\frac{4}{5}x^{-1/5}(x+1)}{x^{8/5}} \right)\\
&= \frac{6x^{-1/5}(x - \frac{4}{5}x - \frac{4}{5})}{5x^{8/5}}\\
&= \frac{6(\frac{1}{5}x - \frac{4}{5})}{5x^{9/5}}\\
&= \frac{6(x-4)}{25x^{9/5}}
\end{align}\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\[\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}\]\\Find the second derivative of \emph{y=f(x)}.

sols:
From parts (a) and (d), we know that the critical values for the first
and second derivative of $f(x)$ are $x = -1, x = 0$, and $x = 4$. We
first calculate the corresponding y-values for the x-values named above
...

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle x = -1$,
  $\displaystyle y = f(-1) = 6(-1)^{1/5} + (-1)^{6/5} = -6 + 1 = -5$
\item
  $\displaystyle  x = 0$,
  $\displaystyle y = f(0) = 6(0)^{1/5} + (0)^{6/5} = 0$
\item
  $\displaystyle  x = 4$,
  $\displaystyle  y = f(4) = 6(4)^{1/5} + (4)^{6/5} \approx 13.2$
\end{itemize}

...and then plot these points on the graph.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1a.jpg}
\caption{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1a.jpg}
\end{figure}

From part (b), we know the function is decreasing until the point
$(-1, -5)$ and then increasing. Thus the function has a minimum at that
point. Because the derivative is undefined at $(0,0)$, it has a vertical
tangent line there.

Schematically, the tangent lines and increase/decrease of the function
looks like this.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1b.jpg}
\caption{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1b.jpg}
\end{figure}

However, we know the function isn't made up of straight lines - it's
more curvy than that. From part (d) we know that the function has an
inflection point at $x = 0$ and $x = 4$. Furthermore we know that the
function is concave up for $x < 0$ and $x > 4$ and is concave down for
$0 < x < 4$. This tells us what our curves should look like.

If we superimpose the curve on top of the straight lines it looks
something like this:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1c.jpg}
\caption{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1c.jpg}
\end{figure}

So the final graph should look like this:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1d-002.jpg}
\caption{Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1d-002.jpg}
\end{figure}
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\[\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}\]\\ Sketch the graph of ''y=f(x) '' and indicate
the inflection points on your graph. Please also indicate the point(s)
on your graph at which the graph of ''y=f(x) '' has a vertical tangent
line.
hints:
A vertical tangent line means that the derivative is undefined at the
point. As for the sketch, use the previous parts of this question to
help with your drawing.

sols:
We are given acceleration and asked to argue about distance. Since the
derivative of a position function is velocity and the derivative of a
velocity function is acceleration, we with to antidifferentiate our
original function twice. This was done in part (a) giving the answer of

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t\]

As this is a position function, we need to check when the particle
reverses direction. This occurs potentially at critical points. We know
the derivative of $f(t)$ is $v(t)$ and so, setting this equal to
zero and solving gives

\[\displaystyle 0 = f'(t) = 6t^{2} - 30t + 36 = 6(t^{2} - 5t + 6) = 6(t-3)(t-2)\]

and hence the critical points are at $t=2,3$. Since we only care about
time up to $t=3$, we only need to check whether the point at $t=2$ is a
maximum or minimum. Using the second derivative test we see that

\[\displaystyle
f''(2) = v'(2) = a(2) = 12(2)-30 = -6 < 0\]

and thus \emph{t=2} is a maximum of $f$. In particular, this means that
our particle changes directions at \emph{t}=2. Thus, we calculate the
total distance traveled up to \emph{t}=2 first then from \emph{t}=2
until \emph{t}=3:

\[\displaystyle
\begin{align}
f(0) & =2(0)^3-15(0)^2+36(0) \\
& = 0
\end{align}\]\\

\[\displaystyle
\begin{align}
f(2) & =2(2)^3-15(2)^2+36(2) \\
& = 2(8)-15(4)+72 \\
& = 16 - 60 + 72 \\
& = 28
\end{align}\]\\

\[\displaystyle
\begin{align}
f(3) & =2(3)^3-15(3)^2+36(3) \\
& = 2(27)-15(9)+108 \\
& = 54 - 135 + 108 \\
& = 27
\end{align}\]\\ The total distance traveled from \emph{t}=0 to
\emph{t}=2 is:

\[\displaystyle
\begin{align}
|f(2)-f(0)| & = |28-0|
& = 28
\end{align}\]

Then, we can calculate the total distance traveled from \emph{t}=2 to
\emph{t}=3:

\[\displaystyle
\begin{align}
|f(3)-f(2)| & = |27-28|
& = 1
\end{align}\]

We add these two values together to obtain the total distance traveled
in the first three seconds, which we find to be 29 metres.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}\\A particle moves in a straight
line according to a law of motion \emph{s} = $f$(\emph{t} ), \emph{t}
$\geq$ 0, where \emph{t} is measured in seconds and \emph{s} in meters.
The acceleration function \emph{a}(\emph{t} ) is given by

\[\displaystyle
a(t)=12t-30\] The velocity after 2 seconds is 0, and $f$(0) = 0.\\\\Find
the total distance travelled by the particle during the first three
seconds.
hints:
When is the position function increasing? When is it decreasing?
Remember that in calculating the \emph{total} ~distance means that
travelling backwards is still covering distance, therefore adding (not
subtracting) to the total distance travelled.

sols:
If you try to evaluate the limit directly, you end up with 0/0, which
means we cannot conclude anything for the moment, more work needs to be
done. Since we have a square root, we will multiply on each side of the
fraction by the conjugate in the hope to simplify things:

\[\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sqrt{x+3}-2}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{(\sqrt{x+3}-2)}{(x-1)}\frac{(\sqrt{x+3}+2)}{(\sqrt{x+3}+2)}\\
&= \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{(x+3)-4}{(x-1)(\sqrt{x+3}+2)}\\
&= \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x-1}{(x-1)(\sqrt{x+3}+2)}\\
&= \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{1}{(\sqrt{x+3}+2)}\\
&= \frac{1}{4}
\end{align}\]
statement:

simplify your answers in this question.}

Evaluate

\[\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sqrt{x+3}-2}{x-1}\] or determine that the limit
does not exist.
hints:
If you try to evaluate the limit directly, you end up with 0/0, which
means we cannot conclude anything for the moment. Factorizing would be a
great idea but because of the square root it is not possible. Hence, how
could we 'get rid' of the square root at the numerator?

sols:
Critical points (numbers) are roots of the derivative. Let's compute
this derivative:

\[f'(x) = \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5}\]

And now find the roots:

\[\frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5} = 0\] We can divide by 6/5

\[\displaystyle
x^{-4/5} = - x^{1/5}\] Now, clearly \emph{x} = 0 is a solution. To find
possibly others, we now assume that \emph{x} isn't zero and now multiply
by \emph{x}\textsuperscript{4/5}

\[\displaystyle
1 = - x\] And obtain a second solution. So we can conclude that there
are two critical points: \emph{x} = 0 and \emph{x} = -1.
Critical points (numbers) are roots of the derivative. Let's compute
this derivative:

\[f'(x) = \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5}\]

And now we can do a little algebra on the function and rewrite as

\[\begin{align}
f'(x) &= \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5} \\
&= \frac{6}{5} x^{1/5} (x^{-1} + 1)
\end{align}\]

And so the critical points are solutions of either

\[\displaystyle
x^{1/5} = 0 \quad \iff \quad x=0\] or

\[\displaystyle
x^{-1}+1 = 0 \quad \iff \quad x=-1\] And so we have two critical points:
\emph{x} = 0 and \emph{x} = -1.

answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\[\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}.\]\\\\ Find the critical numbers of \emph{y} =
$f(x)$.
hints: Critical points (numbers) are roots of the derivative.

statement: No content found

sols:
The general forumla for a second degree Taylor polynomial is:

\[T_2(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\] To find this for
$f(x)$, we need to first find $f'(x)$ and
$f''$(\emph{x}):

\[f'(x)=(\sqrt[3]{x})'=(x^{1/3})'=\frac{1}{3}x^{-2/3}\]

\[f''(x)=(\frac{1}{3}x^{-2/3})'=-\frac{2}{9}x^{-5/3}\] And now we can
evaluate at \emph{a} = 8 to get

\[f(8)=8^{1/3}=2\]

\[f'(8)=\frac{1}{3}8^{-2/3}=\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{4} = \frac{1}{12}\]

\[f''(8)=-\frac{2}{9}8^{-5/3} = -\frac{2}{9} \cdot \frac{1}{2^5} = -\frac{2}{9 \cdot 32} = - \frac{1}{144}\]

We can now plug these in to the equation for the second Taylor
polynomial and obtain:

\[T_2(x)=2+\frac{1}{12}(x-8) - \frac{1}{288}(x-8)^2\] (This is
simplified enough for the purpose of Taylor polynomials).
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required
unless explicitly stated.}

Let \emph{T}\textsubscript{2}(\emph{x}) be the second degree Taylor
polynomial about \emph{a} = 8 for

\[f(x)= \sqrt[3]{x}.\]

Find \emph{T}\textsubscript{2}(\emph{x}) and simplify your answer.
hints:
Recall that the general forumla for a second degree Taylor polynomial
is:

\[T_2(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)+\frac{f''(a)}{2}(x-a)^2\]

sols:
To find the equation of the tangent line to \emph{y} =
\emph{x}\textsuperscript{3.5} - \emph{e}\textsuperscript{3.5} at the
point (\emph{e, 0} ), we must first find the derivative of the curve,
which is the slope of the tangent line at that point.

First we use the difference rule to separate the two terms.

\[\frac{d}{dx}(x^{3.5}-e^{3.5})
=\frac{d}{dx}(x^{3.5})-\frac{d}{dx}(e^{3.5})\]

The next step is to recognize that \emph{e}\textsuperscript{3.5} is a
constant, so we know that its derivative is equal to 0 and we can remove
that term altogether from the equation. Then we use to power rule to
differentiate \emph{x}\textsuperscript{3.5} :

\[\frac{d}{dx}(x^{3.5})
=3.5x^{3.5-1}
=3.5x^{2.5}\]

By plugging in \emph{x} = \emph{e} into the derivative, we find the
tangent line at the desired point (\emph{e}, 0), we get the slope
\emph{m} of the tangent line of equation
\emph{y}-\emph{y}\textsubscript{0} = \emph{m}(\emph{x} -
\emph{x}\textsubscript{0})

\[\displaystyle
m=3.5(e^{2.5})\]

From this we can conclude that the equation of the line is:

\[\displaystyle
y-y_0=m(x-x_0) \quad\Rightarrow\quad y-0=3.5e^{2.5}(x-e)\] Simplifying,
we get

\[\displaystyle
y=3.5e^{2.5}(x-e)\] or

\[\displaystyle
y=3.5e^{2.5}x-3.5e^{3.5}\]

0)}.
hints:
How do you find the slope of the tangent line to a given function at a
specific point?

sols:
We know from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2011/Question_2_(a)}{Question
2 (a)} that the police arrived -ln(4/3)/ln(5/6) hours after the murder
(we add a negative sign because we look at this as a positive amount of
time now).

So the question is whether -ln(4/3)/ln(5/6) is larger than 1 or not.
Let's see if this is meaningful or not. We know that ln(\emph{x}) is
positive if \emph{x} is larger than 1. So ln(4/3) is positive and
ln(5/6) is negative. Since -ln(5/6) = ln(6/5), we can say that the
(positive) amount of time it took for the police to get to the crime
scene is ln(4/3)/ln(6/5).

Which of 4/3 or 6/5 is larger? Well, they are the same as 20/15 and
18/15 respectively, so the denominator is smaller than the numerator and
likewise if we take a logarithm, hence ln(4/3) \textgreater{} ln(6/5)
and so

\[\displaystyle
\frac{\ln(4/3)}{\ln(6/5)} > 1\] which means that the police arrived MORE
than an hour after the murder, that is, the murder took place BEFORE
9:00PM.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required
unless explicitly stated.}

A wealthy man was found murdered in his home. The police arrived on
scene at 10:00 P.M. The temperature of the body at 10:00 P.M. was
33$^{\circ}$C and one hour later it was 31$^{\circ}$C. The temperature
of the room in which the body was found was 21$^{\circ}$C and normal
body temperature is 37$^{\circ}$C. Assume that the body cools after
death according to Newton's Law of Cooling.

Did the murder occur before 9:00 P.M.? Please justify your answer.
hints:
Looking back to
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2011/Question_2_(a)}{
Question 2 (a)}, how long after the murder did the police arrive? When
did the police arrive?

Since you do not have access to a calculator during the exam, how can
you evaluate ln(4/3)/ln(5/6) without a calculator?

Find the derivative of

\[f(x)=\frac{x}{x^2-1}\] Please simplify your answer.
hints:
Use the quotient rule.
The quotient rule is

\[\left(\frac{g}{h}\right)' = \frac{g'h-h'g}{h^2}\]

sols:
We compute this derivative using the chain rule twice and the product
rule

\[\begin{align}
\frac{dy}{dt} &= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot \frac{d}{dt}( t\cos(2t))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot (\frac{d}{dt}(t) \cdot \cos(2t) + t \frac{d}{dt}(\cos(2t)))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \cdot ( 1 \cdot \cos(2t) + t (-\sin(2t) \cdot 2))\\
&= e^{t\cos(2t)} \left( \cos(2t) - 2t\sin(2t) \right)
\end{align}\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box

Find \emph{dy/dt} where

\[\displaystyle
y=e^{t\cos({2t})}\]
hints: Which differentiation rules will you be using here?

sols:
Using the fact that

\[\frac{d}{dx} \sin^{-1}(x) = \frac1{\sqrt{1-x^2}},\] and the chain
rule, we get

\[\begin{align}
\frac{d}{dx} y & = \frac{d}{dx}  \sin^{-1} (3x +1)  \\
 & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(3x+1)^2}} \cdot \frac{d}{dx} (3x+1)    \\
 & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(9x^2+6x+1)}} \cdot 3  \\
 & = \frac{3}{\sqrt{-9x^2 - 6x}}.
\end{align}\]

hints: What is the derivative of $\sin^{-1}(x)$?

sols:
The strength of Newton's method is on root finding. We're asked to
approximate

\[\displaystyle{}x=2^{1/6}\]

which we can write as a root finding problem,

\[\displaystyle{}x^6-2=0.\]

With this in mind, let

\[\displaystyle{}f(x) = x^6-2.\]

Taking the derivative gives

\[\displaystyle{}f'(x) = 6x^5.\]

We start with $x_1=1$ as our first iteration and so if we apply Newton's
Method, we get,

\[x_{2} = x_{1} - \frac{f(x_{1})}{f'(x_{1})} = 1 - \frac{f(1)}{f'(1)} = 1 - \frac{-1}{6} = 1+\frac{1}{6} = \frac{7}{6}.\]

If we actually compute $2^{1/6}$ we get

\[\displaystyle{}2^{1/6}\approx{}1.122462048\]

and so $\frac{7}{6}=1.166666667$ is already in good agreement.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box

incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Use Newton's Method to find the second approximation
\emph{x}\textsubscript{2} to

\[\sqrt[6]{2}\] starting with the inital approximation
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1}=1.
hints:
How can we turn this into a root finding problem?
The formula for Newton's Method is

\[x_{n+1} = x_{n} - \frac{f(x_{n})}{f'(x_{n})}\]

sols:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
$f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}$

Since the functions differ on either side of 1, we will want to use one
sided limit to attempt to evaluate the limit. If the one sided limits
are equal, then the derivative exists. Otherwise, the derivative does
not exist. Firstly, notice that $f(1) = 2(1)+1 = 3$. From the left, we
have

$\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4x-4}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)}}{x-1} \\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4(x-1)}{x-1} - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} 
\end{align}$

Now, to evaluate the last limit, recall that
$\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1$ hence
$\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2} = 1$ and so, multiplying top and
bottom by 4, we have

$\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &=  4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot 4(x-1)^2} \\
&= 4 - \lim_{x \to 1^{-}}\frac{4\sin^2(2x-2)}{3\cdot (2x-2)^2} \\
&= 4 - \frac43 \left( \lim_{x \to 1^-} \frac{\sin(2x-2)}{2x-2}\right)^2 \\
&= 4 - \frac{4}{3} \\
&= \frac{8}{3}
\end{align}$

As for the other side, we have

$\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} &= \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x+1-3}{x-1}\\
&=  \lim_{x \to 1^{+}}\frac{2x-2}{x-1} \\
&=  2 \\
\end{align}$

As the left and right hand limits do not agree, we have that the
derivative does not exist at 1.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}\\Let

\[f(x)= \begin{cases}
4x-\frac{\sin^2(2x-2)}{3x-3}-1, & \textrm{if} \; x<1, \\
2x+1, & \textrm{if} \; x\geq 1.
\end{cases}\]

Use the definition of the derivative to find \emph{$f'$(1)} or
show that \emph{$f'$(1)} does not exist.
hints:
Using the definition of a derivative, we see that
$f'(1) = \lim_{x \to 1}\frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}$
Since the function is defined piecewise and the function is broken up at
1, we will need to use the left and right hand limits to evaluate the
derivative.
Remember that

\[\lim_{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1\]

You will need a variant of this.

sols:
We will need the following formulas:

The volume of the box is given by

\[\displaystyle V = l w h\] Where \emph{l} is the length of the base of
the box, \emph{w} is the width, and \emph{h} is the height.

The material will form the outside of the box, which is the same as its
surface area. The surface area of an open box is given by

\[\displaystyle SA = 2lh + 2wh + lw\] With \emph{l}, \emph{w}, and
\emph{h} as before.

We also know that the length of the base of the box is twice its width.
In an equation, this means

\[\displaystyle l = 2w\]

We can plug this into our volume and surface area formulas to get

\[\displaystyle V = 2w^2h\]

\[\displaystyle SA = 6wh +2w^2\]

We know one more fact. Because we have $24 m^2$ of material, the formula
for surface area must be equal to 24, or

\[\displaystyle 24 = 6wh +2w^2\]

Isolating for \emph{h} yields

\[\displaystyle h = \frac{24-2w^{2}}{6w}\]

(NOTE: In this step we are assuming that the width is not equal to zero,
which makes sense given the physical limitations of our problem, that
is, boxes have positive dimensions). Plugging this into our formula for
volume yields

\[\displaystyle V = 2w^2h = 2w^{2} \cdot \frac{24-2w^{2}}{6w} = \frac{w(24-2w^{2})}{3} = 8w - \frac{2}{3}w^{3}\]

We wish to optimize \emph{V}. Now that is has only one variable,
differentiating yields

\[\displaystyle V' = 8 - 2w^{2}\]

Setting this equal to 0 and solving gives $w^{2} = 4$ and thus that
$w=2$ (where we note again that dimensions must be positive). Looking at
the derivative of volume, a sign chart tells us that$V'(w) > 0$ when
$w < 2$ and $V'(w) > 0$ when $w < 2$. Hence, we have a maximum at
\emph{w}=2. The volume of the box with this width is

\[\displaystyle V(2) = 8(2) - \frac{2}{3}(2)^{3} = 16 - \frac{16}{3} = \frac{32}{3}\]

and this is the maximal volume as required.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

If 24m\textsuperscript{2} of material is available to make a rectangular
storage container with an open top, and if the length of its base is
twice the width, find the largest possible volume of the rectangular
storage container. Please justify that your answer gives indeed the
largest possible volume.
hints:
Try drawing a picture. The object we are looking for is a rectangular
prism with an open top. What is the volume of such an object? What is
the surface area?
Setting \emph{l} to be the length, \emph{w} to be the width and \emph{h}
to be the height, we have

$\begin{align}
V &= lwh \\
SA &= 2lh + 2wh + lw \\
l &= 2w
\end{align}$

where for the surface area above, we keep in mind that our box has no
top.

Since this is an optimization problem, which function are you trying to
maximize? Which functions are the constraints?

sols:
If \emph{s} = $f$(''t \emph{) is the function describing the position of
the particle, then its derivative $f$'(}t '') is its velocity and its
second derivative the acceleration. This means we know that

\[\displaystyle
f''(t) = a(t)\] and so

\[\displaystyle
f''(t) = 12t-30\] Since this is a polynomial in \emph{t} of degree one,
we know that the velocity must be a polynomial of degree 2:

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = at^2+bt+c\] whose derivative is 12\emph{t}-30

\[\frac{d}{dt}\left( at^2+bt+c \right) = 2at+b\] Hence we have

\[\displaystyle
2a = 12 \qquad \text{and} \qquad b=-30\] And so the velocity is

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+c\] for some constant \emph{c}. Since the velocity
after 2 seconds is 0, we actually are being told that $f$'(2)=0 and hence

\[\displaystyle
6 \cdot 4 - 30 \cdot 2 + c = 0 \qquad \Rightarrow c=36\] And so the
velocity is

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+36\] Now, the velocity being the derivative of the
position function, we can deduce that it has to be a polynomial of
degree 3 and write

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = At^3+Bt^2+Ct+D\] and computing its derivative gives us

\[\displaystyle
f'(t) = 3At^2+2Bt+C\] Hence

\[\displaystyle
3A = 6 \qquad \text{and} \qquad 2B=-30 \qquad \text{and} \qquad C=36\]
So the position function is

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t+D\] and we can find out the value of \emph{D}
since we are told that $f$(0) = 0 which gives

\[\displaystyle
D=0\] And so finally, we obtain that the position function is:

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}\\A particle moves in a straight
line according to a law of motion \emph{s} = $f$(\emph{t} ), \emph{t}
$\geq$ 0, where \emph{t} is measured in seconds and \emph{s} in meters.
The acceleration function \emph{a}(\emph{t} ) is given by

\[\displaystyle
a(t)=12t-30\] The velocity after 2 seconds is 0, and $f$(0) = 0.\\\\Find
the position function \emph{s} = $f$(\emph{t} ).
hints: The acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.

sols:
We want to use the intermediate value theorem, as suggested by the
hints. To do this we have to combine the two given functions $f$ and
\emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 3 to one. So define

\[\displaystyle h(x) = f(x)-(2x+3)\]

for \emph{x} in the interval {[}0,1{]}. The function $f$ crosses the line
\emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 3 when both functions are equal, i.e. at zeros of
the function \emph{h}. Since we are asked to show they cross at least
one, we have to show that the function \emph{h} has at least one zero.
In other words, we need to show that there exists a value \emph{c} in
{[}0,1{]} such that \emph{h}(\emph{c}) = 0.

To show this we need to make use of the fact that the range of the
function $f$ is in {[}3,5{]}, i.e.

\[3 \leq f(x) \leq 5\]

for any value of \emph{x} in the domain {[}0,1{]} of the function $f$.
This implies that

\[h(0) = f(0) - (2(0)+3) = f(0)-3 \geq 3-3 = 0.\] and

\[h(1) = f(1) - (2(1)+3) = f(1)-5 \leq 5-5 = 0.\]

Now, in the case that either \emph{h}(0) or \emph{h}(1) actually takes
the value 0, we are done because we have found a zero of \emph{h}.

In the case that neither takes the value zero, then we know that

\[\displaystyle h(1) < 0 < h(0)\]

This is where the Intermediate Value Theorem shines: \emph{h} is a
continuous function on {[}0,1{]}, hence for any value \emph{N} between
\emph{h}(0) and \emph{h}(1) there exists a number \emph{c} =
\emph{c}(\emph{N}) such that

\[\displaystyle h(c) = N.\]

Since we have shown that \emph{h}(0) is negative and \emph{h}(1) is
positive, we can choose that value \emph{N} to be exactly zero and thus
the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees the existence of a number
\emph{c} in the interval {[}0,1{]} such that \emph{h}(\emph{c}) = 0.

Conclusion: At this value \emph{c} we have that

\[0 = h(c) = f(c) - (2c+3)\] or, in other words, \emph{f}(\emph{c}) =
2\emph{c}+3, which is what we had to show.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required
unless explicitly stated.}

If \emph{y} = $f(x)$ is a continuous function with domain {[}0,1{]}
and range in {[}3,5{]}, prove that the line \emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 3
intersects the graph of \emph{y} = $f(x)$ at least once.
hints:
What theorem have you learned that applies to functions that are
continuous on a closed interval? How could you use it for this problem?
The Intermediate Value Theorem states that if $f$ is a continuous function
on a closed interval {[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, and \emph{N} is any
number between $f$(a) and $f$(b), there exists a \emph{c} ~for which
$f$(c)=\emph{N}.

sols:
From
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (c)}{part
(c)}, we know that

\[\begin{align}
f''(x) &= \frac{6(x-4)}{25x^{9/5}}
\end{align}\]

Notice that the potential inflection points are at \emph{x}=0,4, where
$f''$(x)} is either zero or undefined. Doing a sign
chart for this function yields the following. When \emph{x \textless{}
0} we have that $f''$(x) \textgreater{} 0}. When
$0 < x < 4$ we have that $f''$(x) \textless{} 0}.
When $x > 4$ we have that $f''$(x) \textgreater{} 0}.
Hence, the function is concave up on $(-\infty, 0) \cup (4,\infty)$.

''Note: Since the sign of $f''$(x)} changes at both
points, both \emph{x=0} and \emph{x=4} are inflection points. Even
though $f''$(x)} is not defined at \emph{x = 0}.''
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\[\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}\]\\ Find the intervals on which \emph{y=f(x)} is
concave up.
hints:
We already computed the second derivative in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2011/Question 5 (c)}{part
(c)}. Checking where this is positive tells you when your function is
concave up.

sols:
If you try to evaluate the limit directly, you end up with
$\infty$/$\infty$, which means we cannot conclude anything for the
moment, more work needs to be done. Here we have

\[\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x}{\sqrt{9x^2 + x -1}} &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{\frac{\sqrt{9x^2 + x -1}}{x}}  \\
&= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{\frac{\sqrt{9x^2 + x -1}}{\sqrt{x^2}}}  \\
&= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{\sqrt{\frac{9x^2 + x -1}{x^2}}}  \\
&= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{\sqrt{9 + \frac{1}{x} - \frac{1}{x^2}}}  \\
&= \frac{2}{\sqrt{9}} \\
&= \frac{2}{3} .
\end{align}\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Evaluate

\[\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x}{\sqrt{9x^2+x-1}}\] or determine that the
limit does not exist.
hints:
Divide top and bottom by the highest power of \emph{x} before you
proceed.

sols:
The intervals of decrease are the intervals on which the derivative of
the function $f$ is negative. Given that

\[\begin{align}
f'(x) &= \frac{6}{5}x^{-4/5} + \frac{6}{5}x^{1/5} \\
&= \frac{6x^{-4/5}(1+x)}{5} \\
&= \frac{6(x+1)}{5x^{4/5}}
\end{align}\]

Our critical points occur when $x=-1,0$, that is, points on the function
where the derivative is undefined or zero. Writing out a sign chart, we
see that when $x< -1$ we have that $f'(x) < 0$. When $-1 < x< 0$ we have
that $f'(x) > 0$. When $0 < x$ we have that $f'(x) > 0$. Hence the
function is decreasing on $(-\infty,-1)$.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}

Let

\[\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}.\]\\Find the interval(s) of decrease.
hints:
Derivatives can help us detect where functions are decreasing. Try
determining when the derivative is negative.

sols:
When we evaluate the function at $t=-2$ we obtain 0/0. Since this is a
rational function, it means that we can factor $t+2$ in each of the
denominator and numerator:

\[\displaystyle
2t^2+t-6 = (t+2)(2t-3)\] and

\[\displaystyle
t^2-4 = (t+2)(t-2)\] Hence

\[\begin{align}
\lim_{t \to -2}\frac{2t^2+t-6}{t^2-4} &= \lim_{t \to -2}\frac{(t+2)(2t-3)}{(t+2)(t-2)}\\
&= \lim_{t \to -2}\frac{(2t-3)}{(t-2)}\\
= \frac{2(-2)-3}{(-2)-2}\\
= \frac{7}{4}
\end{align}\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Evaluate

\[\lim_{t \to -2} \frac{2t^2+t-6}{t^2-4}\] or determine that the limit
does not exist.
hints:
What happens if you simply plug in -2 in the function? What does it
mean? What can you do about that?
Evaluating at -2 gives 0/0 which is undefined. This means we just don't
know anything about what the limit might be (it could be anything). So
we need to deal with that. Notice that the function is a rational
function (a fraction with polynomials in both numerator and
denominator), since each are 0 at \emph{t}=-2, it means that -2 is a
root of each and hence, they can be factorized.

sols:
The two variables that are changing in this problem are the volume of
water and the height of the water. These two variables are related in
the formula for volume of a cylinder:

\[V = \pi r^2 h\] For this problem, we know that the radius of the
cylinder is 3, so we can put that into our formula to get:

\[V = 9\pi  h\] Since the question is asking about rates of change, we
will differentiate the above formula with respect to \emph{t}.

\[\frac{dV}{dt} = 9\pi\frac{dh}{dt}\] In this new formula, \emph{dh/dt}
stands for the rate at which the height of the water is changing, which
is what we're solving for. We also know that \emph{dV/dt} stands for the
rate at which the volume of water is changing, which is \emph{5
m\textsuperscript{3}/min}. So substituting in \emph{dV/dt = 5} we have:

\[5 = 9\pi\frac{dh}{dt}\] And solving for \emph{dh/dt} we get:

\[\frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{5}{9\pi} m/min\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

A vertical cylindrical tank with radius \emph{3m} is being filled with
water at a rate of \emph{5m\textsuperscript{3}/min}. How fast is the
height of the water increasing?
hints:
What is the relationship between the volume of water being added and the
increase in the water's height?
Recall that the formula for a cylinder's volume is

\[V=\pi r^2h\] Where \emph{r} is the radius of the base and \emph{h} is
the height.

sols:
Our goal is to find \emph{f(3)}. Since \emph{f(x)} is continuous we know
that $f(3) = \lim_{x \to 3} f(x)$ and thus finding \emph{f(3)} amounts
to finding the limit.

Using the limit laws we have

\[1 = \lim_{x \to 3} (xf(x) + g(x)) = \lim_{x \to 3} x \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) + \lim_{x \to 3} g(x).\]
Using that both functions \emph{x} and \emph{g(x)} are continuous, we
have that

\[\lim_{x \to 3} x = 3\] and

\[\lim_{x \to 3} g(x) = g(3) = 2.\] Plugin this into the above equality,
we find

\[1 = 3 \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) + 2\] and hence

\[\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = - \frac{1}{3} .\]

By the first remark above we have

\[\displaystyle f(3) =  - \frac{1}{3}.\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Suppose \emph{f} and \emph{g} are continuous functions such that
\emph{g(3) = 2} and

\[\displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 3} (xf(x) + g(x)) = 1.\] Find \emph{f(3)}.
hints: What limit laws can you use to separate the limit?

sols:
In this case we need to use logarithmic differentiation, indeed it is
impossible to use the power rule since there is an \emph{x
\textsuperscript{2}} as exponent. We cannot differentiate it in the same
way we do for exponential functions since we take the power of \emph{x}
and not \emph{e} or another constant. Hence we need to use logarithmic
differentiation. First set

\[y=x^{(x^2)},\] then taking the logarithm on both sides we find

\[\ln y = \ln (x^{(x^2)}) = x^2 \ln(x).\] Now keeping in mind that
\emph{y} is a function of \emph{x}, we can take the derivatives on both
sides and get

\[\frac{d}{dx} \ln y = \frac{d}{dx} (x^2 \ln(x)) .\] The left-hand side
is simply

\[\frac{d}{dx} \ln y = \frac{1}{y} \cdot \frac{d}{dx} y = \frac{1}{y} y',\]
while the right-hand side gives, using the product rule,

\[\frac{d}{dx}(x^2 \ln(x)) = 2x \ln(x) + x^2 \frac{1}{x} =  2x \ln(x) + x.\]
Putting everything back together, we get

\[\frac{1}{y} y' = 2x \ln(x) + x,\] and thus

\[\displaystyle y' = y (2x \ln(x) + x).\] Replacing \emph{y} by
$x^{(x^2)},$ we finally get

\[y' = x^{(x^2)} ( 2x \ln(x) + x).\]
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Find \emph{f$^{\prime}$(x)}, where

\[f(x)=x^{(x^2)}\]
hints: Can we use the power rule here? Why, or rather, \textbf{why not}?

sols:
Newton's Law of Cooling which states that

\[\displaystyle
T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}\]. Here, the initial temperature of the body
\emph{T}\textsubscript{0} is 33$^{\circ}$C; the temperature of the
environment \emph{T}\textsubscript{a} is given to be 21$^{\circ}$C; and
the temperature of the body after 1 hour (\emph{T}(1)) is 31$^{\circ}$C.
Plugging in these numbers give us

\[\displaystyle
31=21+(33-21)e^{-k}\] Using this equation, we can solve for \emph{k}:

\[\begin{align}
e^{-k} & =\frac{31-21}{33-21}=\frac{5}{6} \\
-k & =\ln(5/6) \\
k & =-\ln(5/6) \\
\end{align}\]

And so now we have found the equation that gives us the temperature of
the body at any time \emph{t}:

\[\displaystyle
T(t) = 21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)}\] and we would like to know the time of
death, which is the time at which the body temperature was
37$^{\circ}$C. For this, we simply solve

\[\displaystyle
T(t) = 37\] that is

\[\begin{align}
21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 37 \\
12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16 \\
e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16/12 \\
t\ln(5/6) &= \ln(4/3) \\
t &= \frac{\ln(4/3)}{\ln(5/6)} \\
t &\approx -1.578
\end{align}\]

Therefore, the police arrived (ln(3/4))/(ln(5/6)) hours after the
murder, that is, roughly an hour and a half.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required
unless explicitly stated.}

A wealthy man was found murdered in his home. The police arrived on
scene at 10:00 P.M. The temperature of the body at 10:00 P.M. was
33$^{\circ}$C and one hour later it was 31$^{\circ}$C. The temperature
of the room in which the body was found was 21$^{\circ}$C and normal
body temperature is 37$^{\circ}$C. Assume that the body cools after
death according to Newton's Law of Cooling.

How many hours before the police arrived on the scene did the murder
occur?
hints:
Recall that Newton's Law of Cooling states that

\[\displaystyle
T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}\] where \emph{T}\textsubscript{a} is the
temperature of the environment; \emph{T}\textsubscript{0} is the initial
temperature of the object; and \emph{T}(\emph{t}) is the temperature of
the object at time \emph{t}.

sols:
In order to find the slope of the tangent line, we need to take the
derivative. However, because this expression is not written in the form
\emph{y = f(x)}, we will have to use implicit differentiation with
respect to \emph{x}.

Thus we implicitly differentiate the expression with respect to
\emph{x}. Note that the term \emph{x\textsuperscript{2}} can be
differentiated directly, the term \emph{xy} requires the product rule,
and the term \emph{y\textsuperscript{2}} requires the chain rule.

\[2x + y + x\frac{dy}{dx} + 2y\frac{dy}{dx} = 0\] Since we are finding a
specific derivative at the point \emph{(0,2)}, we can go ahead and plug
in the values \emph{x=0} and \emph{y=2} to get:

\[2(0) + (2) + (0)\frac{dy}{dx} + 2(2)\frac{dy}{dx} = 0\]

\[2 + 4\frac{dy}{dx} = 0\] If we solve the above expression for the
derivative \emph{dy/dx} we get:

\[\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-2}{4} = \frac{-1}{2}\] So the slope of the
tangent line is -1/2.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Find the slope of the tangent line to the curve \emph{y=f(x)} at the
point \emph{(0,2)}, where the function \emph{y=f(x)} satisfies the
equation

\[\displaystyle
x^2+xy+y^2=4\]
hints:
Is \emph{y}=\emph{$f$}(\emph{x}) implicit or explicit? What method of
differentiation do you need to use?

sols:
The limit definition of the derivative at a point \emph{x=a} is:

\[f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}\]

We notice that the term \emph{cos($\pi$/3 + h)} in the statement of the
question resembles the \emph{f(x+h)} term in the limit definition of the
derivative. If this is the case, \emph{f(x) = cos(x)} and \emph{a =
$\pi$/3}.

We now test these guesses using the limit definition of the derivative.
If \emph{f(x) = cos(x)} and \emph{a = $\pi$/3}, then

\[\begin{align}
f'\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\cos(\frac{\pi}{3} + h) - \cos(\frac{\pi}{3})}{h}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\cos(\frac{\pi}{3} + h) -\frac{1}{2}}{h}
\end{align}\] If we multiply both sides by \emph{2} we get

\[2f'\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{2\cos(\frac{\pi}{3} + h) -1}{h}\]

This is the expression we were trying to find, so our guess of the
function \emph{f(x)} and the value \emph{a} were correct: \emph{f(x) =
cos(x)} and \emph{a = $\pi$/3}.
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Find a function \emph{f(x)} and a number \emph{a} such that

\[2f'(a)=\lim_{h\to 0} \frac{2\cos(\frac{\pi}{3}+h)-1}{h}\]
hints:
What is the limit definition of \emph{f'(x)}? Where is it similar to the
above expression?
It may be useful to know that

\[\displaystyle \cos(\pi/3) = 1/2,\]

or equivalently

\[\displaystyle 2\cos(\pi/3) = 1.\]

sols:
We are being told that the instantaneous rate of change of the function
is at least of 3 on the interval {[}-1,2{]}, so the smallest possible
value of $f$(2) is the case where the function has the smallest rate of
change, that is a constant rate of change of 3 which means it is a
straight line (of slope 3).

And since we are starting at the point (-1,9) with a slope of 3 and a
run of 3 (from -1 to 2) we will end up with a rise of 9 and so the
minimal value of $f$(2) is 18.
Alternatively, you can use the MVT (Mean Value Theorem), which states
that if \emph{f(x)} is defined and continuous on the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} and differentiable on \emph{(a,b)}, then there is at
least one number \emph{c} in the interval \emph{(a,b)} (that is \emph{a
\textless{} c \textless{} b}) such that

$f '(c) = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}$

If we assume $f(x)$ is differentiable on \emph{(-1,2)} and
differentiable and continuous on the interval \emph{{[}-1,2{]}}, we can
use the MVT which gives:

$\frac{f(2)-f(-1)}{2-(-1)} = f'(c)$

For some value \emph{c} in the interval \emph{(-1,2)}. However, we know
that $f'(x) \geq 3$ for any value between -1 and 2, thus,
$f'(c) \geq 3$. Adding this, plugging in known values, and simplifying
gives:

$\frac{f(2) - 9}{3} \geq 3$

Solving for \emph{f(2)} we get $f(2) \geq 18$, thus the minimal value of
\emph{f(2)} is 18.
statement:

If $f$(-1) = 9 and $f'(x)$ $\geq$ 3 for -1 $\leq$ \emph{x} $\leq$ 2,
how small can $f$(2) possibly be?
hints:
What does $f'(x)$ $\geq$ 3 for -1 $\leq$ \emph{x} $\leq$ 2 mean in
terms of the increasing/decreasing of the function $f(x)$ between
-1 and 2?
